Remarks: This beautiful home was just featured in the Deseret News Renovation Design section! Built in 1882, this French European home was fully remodeled under the design of Renovation Design Group and executed by Russell & Co and VB Custom Homes. The wood frame home features all new, plumbing, electrical, drywall, finishes and paint with crown molding, can lights and ceiling fans throughout. Stainless steel appliances highlighted by an 8 burner Wolf stove top compliment the traditional cabinetry designed by Craftsman Kitchens of Salt Lake. The brick back splash and 6mm granite counters serve in contrast to the coffered ceiling, with ceiling fans, in this traditionally styled kitchen flanked by a mudroom with custom storage lockers, walk in pantry and built in storage cabinets. The master bedroom features memory foam carpet pads, built in his/hers closets as well as a full 4 piece bathroom. His and hers furniture style vanities are paired with a walk-in shower and original claw foot soaking tub. A craft room on the 2nd level brings the laundry upstairs along with a utility sink and shower. Custom cabinets by Ted Van Buren include a movable island are made to feature with the amount of natural light brought in from the windows and skylight. The basement is fully finished with a kitchen with 10ft ceilings, 2 bedrooms, a full bathroom, laundry and a dedicated outside entrance. Would make an excellent separate living space for someone. Historical elements like the hand-carved newel post, the original main level windows and the quarter sawn tiger oak fireplace were all preserved to retain the homes place in history. Even the slate tile roof was reclaimed from the Catholic Church of the Madeline in 1980. Every home in the avenues is a unique, must see but few come along that blend modern design with Utah history so well, something you really have to see to believe. Remarks: A peerless example of the style, this Georgian emphasizes classicism, order, and symmetry (and these are a few of our faaa-vorite thiiings). This style of home is most commonly found along the eastern seaboard, where English influence was concentrated, so to stumble upon one of these stunners right here in our own fair city is...well, breathtaking. In the midst of the trendy newcomers and staid all-too-commons, this one will appeal to both folks from easterly climes and those of you who have just admired the stately architecture when you vacationed back east. The Georgian style (named for that numerous succession of English kings we know so well) gained popularity upon arrival in the colonies, as it was translated into countless variations that all shared the classic elements. Details like the center-entry façade, two-room-deep center-passage floor plan (with windows aligned horizontally and vertically), paired chimneys, cornice with dentil moulding, and five-bay façade (among many others) remain intact and beautifully representative of the style here. And to these more traditional elements, you can add a gracious family room, sun room, 3-car garage, beautiful back courtyard, tiered garden (with your very own apricot tree and raspberry patch), and perfectly landscaped water-feature. Oh, and that theater room in the basement? Well, just pop on a flick set in New England–we're thinking Mystic Pizza–and you'll be gazing at Georgians from a Georgian (so meta). By George, this might be your home.     Square footage figures are provided as a courtesy estimate only.  Buyer is advised to obtain an independent measurement.

The roof, boiler, and front and back decks are all brand new; the tiles in the kitchen (imported from a monastery in France), the pantry's hidden subzero drawer, and the wood-burning stove in the sunroom are all thoughtfully-fitting additions, too. The solid wood doors, leaded glass windows, and Japanese maple out back, however, are all original, and stand as true testaments to the timelessness of good style. Remarks: Yes, the rumors are true: this insanely beautiful Federal Heights head-turner is officially up for grab. From the street, this space is striking (and keep-your-eyes-on-the-road at its most hazardous). A towering, modern masterpiece, the hillside home has been lovingly crafted from the ground up. That is to say, it's completely custom. Looking for cookie cutter? Keep walkin'. From the entry (a massive, pivoting door of steel and redwood slats), you're warmly welcomed into a standing ovation-worthy entryway. Vaulted ceilings, windows, and a floor-to-ceiling limestone wall that transitions from outside to in swimmingly. The wall of windows (energy-efficient, no less) opens almost completely, making the living room and back patio one fabulously fluid space. The aforementioned floor-to-ceiling limestone wall, which appears again in the living room, spills out onto the patio and continues along the exterior of the home (continuity at its finest, people). This is indoor/outdoor living oriented around one central gathering space. An entertainer's reverie, the kitchen stands alone as a work of pitch-perfect craftsmanship. The marble countertop was procured from a quarry in Florence, and the result is nothing short of transcendent–but it's the custom backsplash that undoubtedly steals the show. The cabinets and closets are forged from wood salvaged from an old water tower at Kennicott, meaning they're riddled with watermarks, mineral lines, and nail and screw impressions. Essentially: they're perfectly imperfect. Perfectly perfect, though, is the street which this saintly structure sits on. Quiet, cozy, and with city views you wouldn't dream of shaking a stick at. Add a drool worthy backyard (and the totally hidden-from-plain sight pool) and it's all urban oasis. Call it "organic glam." Call it "killer views + total privacy." Call us up. Then call it "home."
